item.description:
Disabling 128 bits ciphers on TLS1.3 on nginx

Module ngx_http_ssl_module

This directive appeared in version 1.19.4.

The server is currently on the same nginx version as Debian bullseye.

Debian -- Details of package nginx in bullseye

1.18.0

Therefore this option isn‚Äôt available yet.

item.title: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
TNT_BOM_BOM:

Which is better than ours which has expired cert with RSA:

This is a non-issue according to letsencrypt. Quote:

letsencrypt.org

DST Root CA X3 Expiration (September 2021) - Let's Encrypt

Update September 30, 2021 As planned, the DST Root CA X3 cross-sign has expired, and we‚Äôre now using our own ISRG Root X1 for trust on almost all devices. For more details about the plan, keep reading! We have also updated our Production Chain...

What should you do? For most people, nothing at all!

Test websites also not showing a warning or downgrade the rating.

TNT_BOM_BOM:

danwin1210 website changed from RSA to ECC P-384:

Moving to a EC 384 bits (SHA384withECDSA) certificate might make sense but there‚Äôs no rush.

TNT_BOM_BOM:

This is i think useful guide by certbot:

User Guide ‚Äî Certbot 1.27.0 documentation

Awesome.

TNT_BOM_BOM:

According to:

Achieving a Perfect SSL Labs Score with Go

This means I need to take the default CipherSuites and simply remove any that use a cipher smaller than 256bit.

We need to remove ciphers which are 128 and keep 256 or above: (for 1.3 and 1.2)

In theory, yes. I tested the author‚Äôs website blog.bracebin.com with ssllabs and it didn‚Äôt have 4x 100%. Therefore it might be outdated and not work anymore. Also instructions aren‚Äôt for nginx so I cannot apply them.

I was also reading:

serverfault.com

Perfect SSL Labs score with nginx and TLS 1.3?

nginx, security, ssl, openssl
asked by Gojira on 01:37AM - 31 Aug 19 UTC

In one reply, the author included a link to a blog post:

Angelique Dawnbringer ‚Äì 27 Oct 19

TLS All The Things! Perfect 100 SSL-Labs Score Revisited

Want to have a "perfect" ssl-labs score? An A+ 100/100/100/100 on SSLLabs that is? Here is my config file/example and ad...

And then tested the author‚Äôs website dawnbringer.net on ssllabs but it has only 2x 100% and 2x 90%.

My website uses Cloudflare as a proxy and waf but scores lower than that. But all my internal hosts use this profile since I only want to use TLS1.2 or newer to begin with. This domain (oceandns) does have the above profile running: Check SSL Labs here. For an ECC/ECDSA enabled site check: here

The test result is ‚Äúonly‚Äù 4x 100% but with an A rather than an A+ rating. So still not the perfection you‚Äôre seeking here.

For an ECC/ECDSA enabled site check: here

Actually outdated. Not ECC/ECDSA. Actually: RSA 4096 bits (SHA256withRSA)
Also affected by the letsencrypt expired root ‚Äúissue‚Äù.

So in summary, I haven‚Äôt seen any server on ssllabs.com, that has:

  • ECC,
  • A+ (not ‚Äúonly‚Äù A),
  • 4x 100%,
  • no letsencrypt expired root ‚Äúissue‚Äù,
  • no other warnings on ssllabs,
  • is nginx based,

that has published its server config so others can reproduce this.

Reply from my preivous post DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple - #27 by Patrick applies.

Read full topic

item.title: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple
item.dc:creator: TNT_BOM_BOM
item.description:
According to:

blog.bracebin.com

blog.bracebin.com

Adventures in software development and getting things done.

This means I need to take the default CipherSuites and simply remove any that use a cipher smaller than 256bit.

We need to remove ciphers which are 128 and keep 256 or above: (for 1.3 and 1.2)

hardenize.com

Hardenize Report: whonix.org

Hardenize continuously monitors security and configuration of your domain name, email servers, and web site.

By this we will have 100% best ciphers, But only best available Key Exchange not 100%.

We can have 100% key exchange but only available now with RSA 4096 (according to daneil its slower) but not with ECC P-521 due to the limitation mentioned above.

More about ssllabs ratings can be found here:

GitHub

SSL Server Rating Guide ¬∑ ssllabs/research Wiki

Contribute to ssllabs/research development by creating an account on GitHub.

Read full topic

item.title: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple
item.dc:creator: TNT_BOM_BOM
item.description:
No support for ECC P-521, only ECC P-384:

Let's Encrypt Community Support ‚Äì 25 May 22

Does Lets Encrypt support secp521r1 (a.k.a. P-521)?

Hi There, Im reading here: (looks no) But here: (looks yes) So which one is correct? ThX!

Reading time: 1 mins üïë Likes: 15 ‚ù§

danwin1210 website changed from RSA to ECC P-384:

hardenize.com

Hardenize Report: danwin1210.de

Hardenize continuously monitors security and configuration of your domain name, email servers, and web site.

So the chain will be:

End-entity certificate ‚Üê E1 ‚Üê ISRG Root X2 ‚Üê ISRG Root X1

Which is better than ours which has expired cert with RSA:

hardenize.com

Hardenize Report: whonix.org

Hardenize continuously monitors security and configuration of your domain name, email servers, and web site.

According to:

letsencrypt.org

ISRG CP v2.5 - Let's Encrypt

ISRG CP v2.5

If the signing key is P-384, the signature MUST use ECDSA with SHA-384. When encoded, the AlgorithmIdentifier MUST be byte-for-byte identical with the following hex-encoded bytes: 300a06082a8648ce3d040303.

This is i think useful guide by certbot:

https://eff-certbot.readthedocs.io/en/stable/using.html#using-ecdsa-keys

Read full topic
item.source: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple

item.title: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple
item.dc:creator: TNT_BOM_BOM
item.description:
Additional, Daniel from danwin1210 said:

Hello,

thanks for the suggestion, but improving the Key Exchange is not possible, as it is not yet supported by Let's Encrypt to issue ECC certificates with more than 384 bits and 521 is also not supported by most browsers anyway. The only way to archive this is by using RSA keys instead of ECC, which is much slower, requires more bandwidth and will eventually get deprecated, as more and more people are migrating to modern ECC keys.

Cipher strength can be limited, but this will break compatibility with some clients. Modern clients will try to use the most secure ciphers first, but there are still some that will break by removing 128 bit ciphers.

Regards,
Daniel

Read full topic
item.source: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple

item.title: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
After reading lots on the topic, I cannot find any authoritative/expert recommendations that recommend/urge to make sure that ssllabs shows 100% Key Exchange and 100% Cipher Strength instead of ‚Äúonly 90%‚Äù on top of an existing A+ rating. On the contrary, most are discouraging it.

The security gain is disputed, cannot be quantified, worsens compatibility, isn‚Äôt common security practice. Even websites that deal with millions or even billions of USD value such as banks and crypto exchanges don‚Äôt go for this. Neither any security-focused operating systems.

Since Whonix isn‚Äôt a web application project, bank or crypto exchange I‚Äôve decided not to attempt to be special here.

In the wider context

  • Trusting the Whonix ‚Ñ¢ Website
  • Transport Layer Security (TLS)

it doesn‚Äôt seem any threat model would be addressed here.

Further research, discussion, implementation could take many more hours and these don‚Äôt seem appropriately allocated in context of other tasks.

Read full topic
item.source: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple

item.title: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/certbot/certbot

Default RSA key bitlength should be 4096

opened 07:12AM - 11 Jun 15 UTC
closed 05:14AM - 22 Jun 15 UTC
kaystrobach

as your mayor idea is security take the maximum possible ... don't use scary def‚Ä¶aults, make it secure by default and let users downgrade if they need to. Thank you for all your efforts

github.com/certbot/certbot

Default RSA key bitlength should be 3072

opened 04:29PM - 04 Jan 16 UTC
HLFH
feature request area: security more-info

[According to NSA](https://apps.nsa.gov/iaarchive/programs/iad-initiatives/cnsa-‚Ä¶suite.cfm) and [ANSSI](http://www.ssi.gouv.fr/uploads/2015/01/RGS_v-2-0_B1.pdf), RSA with 3072 bit-modulus is the minimum to protect up to TOP SECRET. We should not be in the red line of cryptography. This security by default will bring the needed protection for all the Internet users that pass by HTTP webservers powered with Let's Encrypt.

Read full topic

Angelique Dawnbringer ‚Äì 27 Oct 19

TLS All The Things! Perfect 100 SSL-Labs Score Revisited

Want to have a "perfect" ssl-labs score? An A+ 100/100/100/100 on SSLLabs that is? Here is my config file/example and ad...

item.source: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple

item.title: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
These are old posts. What ssllabs considers 100% has changed since. Configs from back then don‚Äôt work anymore nowadays.

Note: there are very, very few websites that have a all 100% green rating on ssllabs. Just found 1 so far:
https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/analyze.html?d=dustri.org&s=212.51.141.142

Testing kicksecure.com nginx config:

ssl_ciphers !ECDHE-ECDSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:!ECDHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:ECDHE-ECDSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:ECDHE-ECDSA-CHACHA20-POLY1305:ECDHE-RSA-CHACHA20-POLY1305:!DHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:DHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384;
ssl_prefer_server_ciphers on;

Visiting with Firefox, clicked on the lock symbol in the URL bar, shows:

TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384, 256 bit keys, TLS 1.3

Already prefect?

SSL Server Test: kicksecure.com (Powered by Qualys SSL Labs) shows A+ (already highest rating) (I have never seen A++ or A+++) but ‚Äúonly‚Äù 90% for Key Exchange and Cipher Strength.

TLS 1.3 (suites in server-preferred order)
TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384 (0x1302) ECDH x25519 (eq. 3072 bits RSA) FS 256
TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256 (0x1303) ECDH x25519 (eq. 3072 bits RSA) FS 256
TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 (0x1301) ECDH x25519 (eq. 3072 bits RSA) FS 128

TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 offends ssllabs and prevents 100%. Disabling that cipher would break the TLSv1.3 standard as per auote RFC 8446 - The Transport Layer Security (TLS) Protocol Version 1.3

A TLS-compliant application MUST implement the TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 [GCM] cipher suite and SHOULD implement the TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384 [GCM] and TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256 [RFC8439] cipher suites (see Appendix B.4).

More reading on the topic:

dustri.org

Disabling 128 bits ciphers on TLS1.3 on nginx

Personal blog of Julien (jvoisin) Voisin

Quote avoid too much security by ssllabs

Avoid Too Much Security

The cryptographic handshake, which is used to establish secure connections, is an operation for which the cost is highly influenced by private key size. Using a key that is too short is insecure, but using a key that is too long will result in ‚Äútoo much‚Äù security and slow operation. For most web sites, using RSA keys stronger than 2,048 bits and ECDSA keys stronger than 256 bits is a waste of CPU power and might impair user experience. Similarly, there is little benefit to increasing the strength of the ephemeral key exchange beyond 2,048 bits for DHE and 256 bits for ECDHE. There are no clear benefits of using encryption above 128 bits.

  • Quote TLS 1.3 Cipher Strength 90%? ¬∑ Issue #636 ¬∑ ssllabs/ssllabs-scan ¬∑ GitHub (bold is mine)

It screws some old clients, and p384 is much slower than p256 (on my VPS it‚Äôs even twice slower than rsa2048), so it‚Äôs better not to use this in production, unless you are extremely paranoid about the possibility of cracking AES-128 and/or EC P-256.

https://blog.germancoding.com/2020/09/18/why-100-isnt-always-the-best-score/

Let's Encrypt Community Support ‚Äì 16 Dec 20

Can I increase the Key Exchange and Cipher Strength I'm using for a 100%...

I'm not sure it its part of the certificate or something else - but does anyone know if its possible - and also how I could start to increase both the Key Exchange and Cipher Strength so I can achieve a 100% score on all 4 bars on SSLABS - or where I...

Reading time: 7 mins üïë Likes: 67 ‚ù§

Test on TLS Logjam Test - Verify CVE-2015-4000 Vulnerability | KeyCDN Tools also looks good.

Not vulnerable to TLS Logjam attacks.

DHE is supported. Server Temp Key: DH, 4096 bits (>= 2048 bits is recommended).

ECDHE is supported.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Fixed.

Policy set on plaintext port

HSTS policies must not be transmitted over insecure channels.

Location: http://whonix.org/

This was a non-issue for security. Only a warning. But to add kicksecure.com to hstspreload.org it needed to be fixed anyhow.

Status: kicksecure.com is currently preloaded, but has the following issues:

(And the whonix.org and kicksecure.com server share the same private server configuration package with string/replace whonix.org/kicksecure.com where needed.)

Read full topic

item.description:
• No security impact. It‚Äôs a non-issue issue besides the annoying warning.
  • Silencing the warning would result in loosing some device support. These devices would TLS errors which would probably cause more alarm than this.

Will document on and refer to Website and Server Tests instead.

item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/analyze.html?d=whonix.org&s=95.216.25.250&latest

In trust store DST Root CA X3 Self-signed
Fingerprint SHA256: 0687260331a72403d909f105e69bcf0d32e1bd2493ffc6d9206d11bcd6770739
Pin SHA256: Vjs8r4z+80wjNcr1YKepWQboSIRi63WsWXhIMN+eWys=
RSA 2048 bits (e 65537) / SHA1withRSA
Valid until: Thu, 30 Sep 2021 14:01:15 UTC
EXPIRED
Weak or insecure signature, but no impact on root certificate

See:

letsencrypt.org

Certificate Compatibility - Let's Encrypt

The main determining factor for whether a platform can validate Let‚Äôs Encrypt certificates is whether that platform trusts ISRG‚Äôs ‚ÄúISRG Root X1‚Äù certificate. Prior to September 2021, some platforms could validate our...

Let's Encrypt Community Support ‚Äì 7 Oct 21

Long (default) and Short (alternate) Certificate Chains Explained

If you're wondering about the long/default and short/alternate certificate chains and their relationship to the recent DST Root CA X3 expiration, you're in the right place. Which chain am I using? You can check here: ...

Reading time: 2 mins üïë Likes: 9 ‚ù§

search terms:

  • site:letsencrypt.org short chain

  • site:letsencrypt.org long chain

  • site:letsencrypt.org Weak or insecure signature, but no impact on root certificate

Interesting.

If it‚Äôs not in nginx it seems too hacky and not worth potential trouble since there is no clear threat model.

For general context:

Whonix ‚Äì 20 Jun 21

Website and Server Tests

item.dc:creator: TNT_BOM_BOM
item.description:
@patrick Gabe from grapheneos said:

you could also save people battery on phones without AES

ssl_conf_command Options PrioritizeChaCha;

this means that on devices without AES support, chacha20 is preferred over AES

its faster and should use less battery

helpful for people who dont have good hardware

he actually gave alot of advises this is one of them, thanks to him and to @madaidan who told me where to go.

Read full topic

item.title: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple
item.dc:creator: TNT_BOM_BOM
item.description:
Patrick:

nginx support is lacking

#812 (Fetch OCSP responses on startup, and store across restarts) ‚Äì nginx

There is a workaround GrapheneOS using it:

github.com

GitHub - tomwassenberg/certbot-ocsp-fetcher: A tool that primes the OCSP cache...

A tool that primes the OCSP cache of nginx for certificates managed by Certbot, in order to make OCSP stapling work reliably. - GitHub - tomwassenberg/certbot-ocsp-fetcher: A tool that primes the O...

github.com

GitHub - GrapheneOS/nginx-rotate-session-ticket-keys: Session ticket key...

Session ticket key rotation scripting / systemd units for nginx to work around the lack of built-in support. This may eventually be extended to support syncing keys across a group of servers provid...

for TLS session keys

also you‚Äôll need to provision a certificate with the must staple parameter (if not already)

grapheneos nginx:

github.com

GrapheneOS/grapheneos.org/blob/ab50ee229058adc1a7e33e37690edd342d10895b/nginx/nginx.conf#L61

    
      
    
          
  1. ssl_session_ticket_key session-ticket-keys/4.key;
    2. 
          
  2. ssl_session_ticket_key session-ticket-keys/3.key;
    3. 
          
  3. ssl_session_ticket_key session-ticket-keys/2.key;
    4. 
          
  4. ssl_session_ticket_key session-ticket-keys/1.key;
    5. 
          
  5. ssl_buffer_size 4k;
    6. 
          
  6. 
          
    7. 

  7. ssl_trusted_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/grapheneos.org/chain.pem;
    8. 
          
  8. ssl_stapling on;
    9. 
          
  9. ssl_stapling_verify on;
    10. 
          
  10. # maintained by certbot-ocsp-fetcher
    11. 
          
  11. ssl_stapling_file ocsp-cache/grapheneos.org.der;
    12. 
          
  12. 
          
    13. 

  13. log_format main '$remote_addr - $remote_user [$time_local] '
    14. 
          
  14.                 '"$request_method $scheme://$host$request_uri $server_protocol" $status $body_bytes_sent '
    15. 
          
  15.                 '"$http_referer" "$http_user_agent"';
    16. 
          
  16. access_log /var/log/nginx/access.log main buffer=64k flush=1m;
    17. 
          
  17. error_log /var/log/nginx/error.log;
    18. 
          
  18. log_not_found off;
    19. 
          
  19. 
          
    20. 

  20. gzip_proxied any;
    21. 
          
  21. gzip_vary on;
    22.

item.description:
Patrick:

nginx support is lacking

Checking grapheneos website they are using nginx + must staple:

https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/analyze.html?d=grapheneos.org&s=192.99.43.50

can you recheck again?

item.title: DNS Certification Authority Authorization (CAA) Policy / DNSSEC for whonix.org / ssllabs.com test results / OCSP ERROR: Exception: connect timed out [http://r3.o.lencr.org] / Must-Staple
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
I missed that. Looked into that now.

Not even whonix.org's CA is doing that.

https://web.archive.org/web/20210507054847/https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/analyze.html?d=certbot.eff.org&hideResults=on

https://web.archive.org/web/20210507055901/https://www.ssllabs.com/ssltest/analyze.html?d=letsencrypt.org&s=138.68.234.180&latest=

OCSP Must Staple No

nginx support is lacking

https://trac.nginx.org/nginx/ticket/812

Quote mnordhoff Community Moderator;

Let's Encrypt Community Support ‚Äì 12 Apr 20

OCSP stapling issue with Nginx

That‚Äôs just how Nginx works. If the worker process (I believe) doesn‚Äôt have an OCSP response cached, it doesn‚Äôt wait. It handles the connection without OCSP stapling, and fires off an OCSP request in the background. The only web servers with...

APNIC Blog ‚Äì 15 Jan 19

Is the web ready for OCSP Must-Staple? | APNIC Blog

Guest Post: What do clients and web servers need to do to support OSCP Must-Staple?

Est. reading time: 4 minutes

‚ÄúNo, the web is not ready.‚Äù

So, no. For now, not a good idea. Possibly in future. Thanks for bringing that up!

Read full topic

item.description:
Patrick:

Most likely nothing wrong on whonix.org.

Yes, if you scan whonix again now doesnt show the error.

Didnt expect ssllabs would give false positive‚Ä¶ my bad.

TNT_BOM_BOM:

Enable Must-Staple

Not good?
